title: SWE Intern Technical Rubric

dimensions.name: communication
dimensions.description: Clarity, structure, and precision of explanations.

levels.description: Unclear, disorganized, or missing key steps.
Understands basics but explanations have gaps.
Clear, structured explanation with good pacing.
Concise, precise, and easy to follow end-to-end.

dimensions.name: problem_solving
dimensions.description: Ability to frame the problem, plan an approach, and adapt.

levels.description: Struggles to frame the problem or choose an approach.
Finds a workable approach with some guidance.
Solid plan with good decomposition and trade-offs.
Elegant strategy with strong insight and flexibility.

dimensions.name: correctness_reasoning
dimensions.description: Soundness of reasoning, correctness proof, and invariants.

levels.description: Incorrect or lacks reasoning for correctness.
Some reasoning but gaps or unsupported claims.
Clear reasoning with key invariants covered.
Rigorous, complete correctness reasoning.

dimensions.name: complexity
dimensions.description: Accuracy of time/space analysis and optimization awareness.

levels.description: No complexity analysis or clearly incorrect.
Basic analysis but incomplete or slightly off.
Accurate time and space analysis, mentions trade-offs.
Thorough analysis with optimization insight.

dimensions.name: edge_cases
dimensions.description: Identification and handling of edge cases and constraints.

levels.description: Misses key edge cases or constraints.
Mentions some edge cases, incomplete coverage.
Covers major edge cases and constraints.
Comprehensive edge cases and robust handling.

dimensions.name: data_structure_familiarity
dimensions.description: Knowledge of common data structures and when to apply them.

levels.description: Unfamiliar with basic data structures.
Knows arrays, lists, hash tables but may choose poorly.
Good selection of appropriate data structures with justification.
Excellent understanding of multiple structures and trade-offs.

dimensions.name: algorithm_basics
dimensions.description: Understanding of fundamental algorithms and patterns.

levels.description: Unable to implement basic algorithms.
Can implement with hints; recognizes some patterns.
Solid grasp of common algorithms; chooses appropriately.
Strong pattern recognition; can adapt algorithms to novel problems.

dimensions.name: code_completion
dimensions.description: Ability to write syntactically correct, working code.

levels.description: Code has major syntax errors or doesn't compile.
Works for basic cases but has small bugs.
Correct implementation with minimal issues.
Flawless execution with clean syntax.

dimensions.name: code_organization
dimensions.description: Variable naming, function decomposition, and readability.

levels.description: Poor naming, monolithic functions, messy.
Adequate naming but could be cleaner.
Good naming, reasonable function size, logical flow.
Excellent organization; self-documenting code.

dimensions.name: debugging_approach
dimensions.description: Methodology for identifying and fixing issues.

levels.description: Guesses randomly; no systematic approach.
Uses print statements but lacks strategy.
Systematic hypothesis testing with debugging tools.
Efficient root cause identification; preventive mindset.

dimensions.name: learning_agility
dimensions.description: Ability to understand new concepts and apply them during interview.

levels.description: Struggles to incorporate hints or new information.
Accepts hints but applies them slowly.
Quickly incorporates feedback and improves solution.
Learns and adapts rapidly; asks insightful clarifying questions.

dimensions.name: fundamentals_knowledge
dimensions.description: Core computer science concepts (OOP, recursion, etc.).

levels.description: Major gaps in foundational knowledge.
Understands basics but lacks depth.
Solid grasp of core concepts and can apply them.
Strong understanding with ability to explain nuances.

dimensions.name: system_thinking_basics
dimensions.description: Understanding of how components interact (simple systems).

levels.description: Focuses only on isolated code; no system view.
Acknowledges other components but vague.
Clear understanding of client-server, API, database roles.
Articulates end-to-end flow with component interactions.

dimensions.name: testing_awareness
dimensions.description: Understanding of why and how to test code.

levels.description: No consideration of testing.
Mentions testing but not specific.
Identifies key test cases and edge cases.
Comprehensive test strategy; understands testability.

dimensions.name: intellectual_curiosity
dimensions.description: Asks questions, shows interest in learning, explores beyond requirements.

levels.description: Passive; answers only what is asked.
Occasionally asks clarifying questions.
Engages with problem; explores constraints and extensions.
Deep curiosity; discusses trade-offs and alternatives unprompted.

dimensions.name: time_management
dimensions.description: Pacing during interview and ability to prioritize.

levels.description: Spends too long on details; doesn't finish.
Completes solution but rushed at end.
Good pace with time for verification.
Excellent pacing; prioritizes correctly; has buffer for questions.

overall_scoring: Compute the overall score as the average of all dimension scores, scaled to 0-100 and rounded.

intern_easy.description: Single concept, straightforward implementation, minimal edge cases.
intern_easy.example: Two sum, reverse string, find maximum, valid parentheses.

intern_medium.description: Multiple considerations, optimization awareness, some trade-offs.
intern_medium.example: LRU cache design, merge intervals, course schedule, number of islands.

intern_hard.description: Complex patterns, system design basics, deeper trade-off analysis.
intern_hard.example: Design URL shortener, rate limiter, web crawler basics.

scoring_tips: Score based on demonstrated ability, not potential.
Consider that interns are early in their learning journey - be reasonable about expectations.
Look for problem decomposition before implementation.
Value intellectual curiosity and learning agility highly.
Partial credit is appropriate; interns may need hints.
How they respond to feedback is as important as initial performance.
common_pitfalls: Candidate memorized solutions but cannot explain reasoning.
Candidate freezes on unfamiliar problem variation.
Candidate ignores constraints (e.g., memory limits for large input).
Candidate cannot articulate why one approach is better than another.
Candidate rushes to code without planning.
probing_questions: Can you explain that in another way?
What would happen if the input was very large?
What's the simplest version of this problem?
Can you think of an alternative approach?
What's the one thing you'd improve if you had more time?

growth_opportunity_phrases: Practice analyzing time and space complexity
Explore more data structures and their trade-offs
Work on explaining reasoning before coding

amazon_intern.behavioral_integration: Look for customer-centric reasoning even in technical answers.
amazon_intern.example_feedback: Strong problem decomposition; consider adding more thorough edge case coverage.

google_intern.behavioral_integration: Value candidates who explore alternatives and ask insightful questions.
google_intern.example_feedback: Excellent optimization discussion; great curiosity about scalability.

microsoft_intern.behavioral_integration: Look for collaborative problem-solving and clear communication.
microsoft_intern.example_feedback: Clean, maintainable code; good instinct for validation and testing.

apple_intern.behavioral_integration: Attention to detail and user experience considerations.
apple_intern.example_feedback: Meticulous edge case handling; thinks about end-to-end user impact.
